data.title: Skibidiest challenge
data.statement:
In the land of Ohio, there's a famous challenge called the Skibidi Challenge. Legend has it that whoever can find the secret gyatt will unlock the ultimate power of rizz. But to get to the gyatt, you must pass through a series of coded messages.

Your task is to process a list of strings and check if the word {{ohio}} and the word {{gyatt}} both appear in the message. However, there's a twist.

The message is a list of strings.
If the word {{ohio}} appears before {{gyatt}}, output {{YES}}.
If {{gyatt}} appears before {{ohio}}, output {{NO}}.
If either word is missing, output {{MISSING}}.

The messages may contain spaces, punctuation, and other characters, but only the exact words {{ohio}} and {{gyatt}}, in lowercase only (i.e. case-sensitive), are important for the comparison.

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testIn:
4
I went to ohio and found the gyatt.
I found the gyatt after ohio.
I just went to ohio today.
This message does not contain the words.

testCases.title: Validator 1
testCases.testIn:
4
ohio gyatt.
 gyatt ohio.
 ohio .
This message does not contain the words.

testCases.title: Test 2
testCases.testIn:
2
ohIo and gyaTt are amazing.
I found a gYatt but no ohiO.

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testIn:
2
oHio and Gyatt are amazing.
I found a GYATT but no OHIO.

testCases.title: Test 3
testCases.testIn:
2
ohio and gyatt are amazing.
I found a gyatt but no ohio.

testCases.title: Validator 3
testCases.testIn:
2
ohio and gyatt are amazing.
I found a gyatt but no ohio :((.

testCases.title: Validator 4
testCases.testIn:
1
Just some Gyatt ohio is here.

testCases.title: Test 5
testCases.testIn:
2
Ohio then Gyatt then gyatt before ohio
ohiO then gyaTT then ohio before gyatt

testCases.title: Validator 5
testCases.testIn:
2
OhiO thEn GyAtt then OHIO gyatt OHIO before ohio
OhiO then gyaTT then ohio before gyatt

data.constraints:
1 ≤ [[n]] ≤ 10
1 ≤ length of [[message]] ≤ 100
{{ohio}} and {{gyatt}} appear at most once in [[message]].
data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read message:string(1000)
loop n write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: An integer [[n]], which represents the number of messages.
<<Next [[n]] lines>>: A string [[message]].
data.outputDescription:
<<[[n]] lines>>: For each message output one of the following results:

{{YES}} if the word {{ohio}} appears before the word {{gyatt}}.
{{NO}} if the word {{gyatt}} appears before the word {{ohio}}.
{{MISSING}} if either {{ohio}} or {{gyatt}} is missing from the message.
Each result should be printed on a new line corresponding to the respective message in the input.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

In the land of Ohio, there's a famous challenge called the Skibidi Challenge. Legend has it that whoever can find the secret gyatt will unlock the ultimate power of rizz. But to get to the gyatt, you must pass through a series of coded messages.

Your task is to process a list of strings and check if the word ohio and the word gyatt both appear in the message. However, there's a twist.

The message is a list of strings.
If the word ohio appears before gyatt, output YES.
If gyatt appears before ohio, output NO.
If either word is missing, output MISSING.

The messages may contain spaces, punctuation, and other characters, but only the exact words ohio and gyatt, in lowercase only (i.e. case-sensitive), are important for the comparison.
Input
Line 1: An integer n, which represents the number of messages.
Next n lines: A string message.
Output
n lines: For each message output one of the following results:

YES if the word ohio appears before the word gyatt.
NO if the word gyatt appears before the word ohio.
MISSING if either ohio or gyatt is missing from the message.
Each result should be printed on a new line corresponding to the respective message in the input.
Constraints
1 ≤ n ≤ 10
1 ≤ length of message ≤ 100
ohio and gyatt appear at most once in message.
Example
Input
4
I went to ohio and found the gyatt.
I found the gyatt after ohio.
I just went to ohio today.
This message does not contain the words.
Output
YES
NO
MISSING
MISSING
